Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186,.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186, § 14, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees tenants the right to use and enjoy their leased premises free from substantial interference by their landlord.

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 218,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 218, § 19.

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 100-.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that landlords violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment when they engage in or allow substantial and unreasonable interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment of their homes.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 100-.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that, under Massachusetts law, liability does not require malicious intent but arises when the landlord’s conduct has the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of interrupting the tenant’s rights, i.e., serious interference with use of the premises. It cites and incorporates prior Massachusetts cases like Westland Housing, Shindler, and Blackett, characterizing quiet enjoyment as freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. That aligns with the proposition that substantial and unreasonable interferences with tenants’ use and enjoyment violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 100-.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord … more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381-383 (1942). Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33 (1933).”}

Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”
